population_specificity: 20-year-old male with a transverse posterior wall acetabular fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on factors associated with frailty in older adults, including the role of maximal walking speed.
results_summary: The study found that maximal walking speed was significantly associated with frailty (SMD -0.97, 95% CI -1.25 to -0.68), indicating slower walking speed correlates with higher frailty levels.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60 years and over, primarily community-dwelling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of walking ability in geriatric rehabilitation inpatients and assess the feasibility and effectiveness of progressive resistance exercise training (PRT) for those without independent walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that 52.2% of inpatients could not walk independently at admission, with longer stays and lower improvements in independence for these patients. PRT improved walking ability (FAC) and activities of daily living (ADL) compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Geriatric rehabilitation inpatients (median age 83.5 years; 58.0% female).
effective_dosage: PRT sessions were given twice per weekday (relative median number of sessions: 11 out of 44).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the causal role of consistent context in developing a walking habit and its impact on increasing and maintaining physical activity in insufficiently active adults.
results_summary: Consistent context planners developed and maintained habit automaticity but did not show walking maintenance. Participants with stronger habit automaticity maintained walking more post-intervention, and those with routine schedules developed habits even without planning.
population_specificity: Insufficiently active, working, midlife adults (n=127)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the type, amount, and timing of gross motor practice, including walking, during physical therapy sessions for young children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Toddlers with CP spent a small portion of therapy time moving (16.3%), with more than half of the time spent in sitting and standing (60.3%). Transitions between postures occurred most frequently (49.3 per session).
population_specificity: Young children with cerebral palsy (mean age 22.1 months) who could initiate pulling to stand but were unable to walk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using a robotic exoskeleton (EAW) alongside a wheelchair improved mental and physical health outcomes compared to wheelchair use alone in veterans with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvements in mental or physical health outcomes with EAW use, likely due to low device usage, partly caused by FDA-mandated companion unavailability. Two EAW-related foot fractures and nine unrelated fractures (mostly during wheelchair transfers) were reported.
population_specificity: Veterans with spinal cord injury (median age 47, 94% male, median time since SCI 7.3 years).
effective_dosage: At-will use of an FDA-cleared exoskeletal-assisted walking device in the home and community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of arch contouring foot orthoses for relieving pain and improving function, physical activity, and health-related quality of life in people with midfoot osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study will assess the effects of arch contouring foot orthoses versus flat sham inserts on midfoot pain, function, physical activity, and quality of life, with primary outcomes measured at 12 weeks. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling people with painful midfoot osteoarthritis (n=140).
effective_dosage: Not specified (arch contouring foot orthoses vs. flat sham inserts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nordic walking improves function in patients with heart failure (HF) with low left ventricular ejection fraction more than conventional cardiac rehabilitation or usual care.
results_summary: The study found that Nordic walking was associated with increased peak VO₂ and improved functional capacity in patients with chronic HF, particularly those with systolic dysfunction. The meta-analysis of four RCTs showed pooled benefits compared to conventional rehabilitation or usual care.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure and low left ventricular ejection fraction (systolic dysfunction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the baseline characteristics and disease severity of patients with LAMA2-related muscular dystrophy (LAMA2-RD) in Switzerland.
results_summary: The study found that 14 of 18 patients had the severe form of LAMA2-RD (never able to walk), while 4 had the milder form (present or lost walking capability). Brain MRI abnormalities were common, including white matter changes and structural abnormalities.
population_specificity: Patients with LAMA2-RD in Switzerland (median age 8.7 years, range 1 month - 31 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of digitally based motor interventions (e.g., exergaming, virtual reality) on motor outcomes in individuals with developmental disabilities (DD) and intellectual disabilities (ID).
results_summary: The review found strong and consistent evidence of small-to-large improvements in motor skill performance following digital movement interventions, supporting their use for individuals with DD without ID. Digital technologies were noted as engaging options for therapists and caregivers to promote motor skill development.
population_specificity: Children and young adults with developmental disabilities (DD) and intellectual disabilities (ID), excluding those with significant walking challenges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dapagliflozin on physical activity measures, including walking, in heart failure patients using wearable accelerometers.
results_summary: Dapagliflozin improved selected accelerometer-based measures of physical activity, such as step count and time spent in moderate-to-vigorous activity, but did not improve 6-minute walk distance. The study suggests accelerometer data may complement traditional functional outcome measures.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure across the entire left ventricular ejection fraction spectrum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical correlates of obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) in idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH) patients, particularly its impact on motor and cognitive performance.
results_summary: OSA was highly prevalent in iNPH patients (50%), with moderate to severe cases (63.2%) associated with worse motor performance (longer time and more steps to walk 10 m) and poorer cognitive test scores. OSA+ iNPH patients also had higher CSF levels of neurodegeneration biomarkers (total tau and phospho-tau).
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program (including physical exercise, nutritional, and psychological support) could improve functional capacity in colorectal cancer patients undergoing elective resection, as measured by the 6-Minute Walking Test (6MWT).
results_summary: The prehabilitation group showed significant improvements in 6MWT distance pre-operatively (96 m increase) and maintained these improvements at 4 and 8 weeks post-surgery (103 m and 90 m increases, respectively). No significant differences were found in postoperative complications or hospital length of stay between groups.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years) undergoing elective colorectal resection for colon cancer, excluding those with metastatic disease, severe walking impairments, renal failure stage >2, ASA score >3, or preoperative chemo-radiation therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (trimodal prehabilitation included physical exercise, nutritional, and psychological support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether exergames enhance participant enjoyment and training intensity in gait rehabilitation for neurological disorders.
results_summary: The review found that while enjoyment and training intensity are commonly cited rationales for using exergames, these effects are often assumed rather than measured, with only 12 studies assessing enjoyment and seven assessing training intensity.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological disorders (stroke, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether routine walking activity and the derived neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio are associated with outcomes in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.
results_summary: Walking one hour per day was independently associated with improved progression-free survival and overall survival in the studied patient population. A low derived neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio also predicted better overall survival but not progression-free survival.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck treated with immunotherapy.
effective_dosage: 1 hour per day of uninterrupted physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of light-intensity physical activity snacks (including walking) versus prolonged sitting on inflammatory and cardiometabolic risk markers.
results_summary: The study found that light-intensity physical activity snacks, including walking, may influence inflammatory and cardiometabolic risk markers, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome details.
population_specificity: Seventeen young adults with overweight and obesity (eight females, mean age 23.4 ± 3.3 years, BMI 29.7 ± 3.8 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of inhaled treprostinil on hemodynamics and exercise capacity in Japanese patients with PH-ILD.
results_summary: Inhaled treprostinil improved hemodynamics (PVRI decreased by 40.1%) and exercise capacity (6MWD increased by 13.0 m) with a favorable safety profile, though adverse events like cough and malaise were reported.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with pulmonary hypertension associated with interstitial lung disease (PH-ILD).
effective_dosage: 3 breaths (18 μg)/session four times daily, gradually increased to a maximum of 12 breaths (72 μg)/session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether the beneficial effects of empagliflozin on cardiac remodeling and physical capacity in heart failure patients were related to changes in iron metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that empagliflozin increased myocardial iron content, which correlated with improvements in left ventricular function, peak oxygen consumption, and 6-minute walking distance, suggesting enhanced hematopoiesis as a potential mechanism for its clinical benefits.
population_specificity: Stable non-diabetic patients with systolic heart failure and a high prevalence of iron deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current understanding of VLDL metabolism and its implications for novel therapeutic avenues in cardiometabolic disorders.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings related to walking; it focuses on VLDL metabolism and its role in cardiometabolic dysfunction, highlighting gaps in current treatments for CVD and MASLD.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses general VLDL metabolism and cardiometabolic disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gait symmetry and changes before and after unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA) using the Walkway analyzer.
results_summary: The study found that patients with knee osteoarthritis had asymmetric gait pre-operatively, with time indices compensating for the painful side, but these asymmetries disappeared post-operatively. The Walkway analyzer effectively detected these changes, suggesting its utility for objective gait evaluation in clinical practice.
population_specificity: 38 healthy participants and 34 participants with knee osteoarthritis who underwent unilateral TKA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three bleaching techniques (walking bleach, inside/outside, and in-office) for non-vital teeth whitening.
results_summary: All techniques significantly improved tooth whitening, with hydrogen peroxide-based methods (HP7.5 and HP35) showing faster results compared to sodium perborate (SP), though all were equally effective by treatment completion.
population_specificity: Discolored non-vital teeth (54 teeth across three treatment groups).
effective_dosage: Walking bleach (sodium perborate), inside/outside (7.5% hydrogen peroxide), in-office (35% hydrogen peroxide).
study_duration: Weekly evaluations until 1-week follow-up (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining rTMS and AOT interventions improves walking ability and motor function in children with spastic cerebral palsy more effectively than either treatment alone or conventional therapy.
results_summary: The combined intervention of rTMS and AOT significantly improved balance function, walking ability, and gross motor function in children with SCP, outperforming conventional treatment and individual interventions. The combined group showed 87.50% gross motor function efficiency compared to 25.00% in the conventional group.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (SCP)
effective_dosage: Five days per week for 12 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rivaroxaban plus aspirin improves intermittent claudication (walking distance) in adults with lower-risk peripheral arterial disease compared to aspirin alone.
results_summary: The rivaroxaban-plus-aspirin group showed a significant improvement in total walking distance (89 ± 18 m) compared to the aspirin-alone group (21 ± 16 m), with an absolute difference of 68 ± 24 m (P=0.007). No major bleeding events were observed in either group.
population_specificity: Adults with peripheral artery disease and intermittent claudication (mean age 67 years, 54% female).
effective_dosage: 2.5 mg rivaroxaban twice daily plus 100 mg aspirin once daily (intervention group); 100 mg aspirin once daily (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical, neuroimaging, and genetic spectrum of PLAN (phospholipase-associated neurodegeneration) in a cohort of patients.
results_summary: The study identified walking difficulty as a common initial symptom (26.9%) in PLAN patients, alongside other motor and non-motor symptoms. Neuroimaging revealed cerebellar atrophy in most patients (88.5%), and levodopa responsiveness was noted in many with parkinsonism/dystonia.
population_specificity: 26 patients (22 families, 15 males) with genetically-confirmed PLAN, median age 22.5 years, onset at 13.0 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the impact of physical activity and exercise interventions, particularly walking speed and muscle strength, in adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no improvement in walking speed over 10 meters but identified improvements in lower limb muscle strength. The study highlights the need for further research on psychosocial outcomes and long-term participation sustainability.
population_specificity: Adults with cerebral palsy (CP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare demographic, clinical features, and outcomes (including walking-related measures) among early-onset, adult-onset, and late-onset multiple sclerosis patients.
results_summary: The study found that late-onset MS patients had worse lower extremity function (longer T25FW and TUG times) and higher disability scores compared to early-onset and adult-onset MS patients. Walking performance and disability progression differed significantly across the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with early-onset (<18 years), adult-onset (20-40 years), and late-onset (>55 years) multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of walking-only interventions on physical function, fall-related outcomes, and health-related quality of life in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: Walking-only interventions improved walking endurance and health-related quality of life, but no significant improvements were observed in other outcomes. The certainty of the evidence was graded as very low due to inconsistency and imprecision.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: To determine if early comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation, including walking, is safe and effective for hospitalized patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
results_summary: The early comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation group showed significant improvement in 6-min walking distance and inspiratory muscle strength compared to usual care, with no adverse events reported. No significant differences were found in quality of life or breathlessness between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
study_duration: From admission to discharge (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the walking performance of chronic stroke patients using a new carbon fibre ankle foot orthosis (C-AFO), their personal custom-made plastic AFO (P-AFO), and no orthosis (No-AFO).
results_summary: Both AFO conditions (C-AFO and P-AFO) significantly improved walking speed, stride length, step length, and reduced energy cost compared to no orthosis, with no significant differences between the two AFO types.
population_specificity: Fifteen chronic stroke patients (3 women, 12 men; average age 59 years, average 13 years since injury).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was orthosis use, not a dosage).
study_duration: Short habituation period (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a full-scale RCT to evaluate the beneficial effects of Virtual Walking combined with therapeutic exercise on neuropathic pain and functionality in people with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found high participant compliance (80%+ session completion), no dropouts, and no serious adverse events. Preliminary results suggest the experimental intervention (Virtual Walking plus therapeutic exercise) may be effective for improving pain and functionality.
population_specificity: People with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for domino osteoporotic vertebral fractures (OVFs) and assess their impact on patients' quality of life, including walking ability.
results_summary: Walking ability was poorer in patients with domino OVFs compared to those without, and groups with 3 or more adjacent domino OVFs showed worse pain and disability scores. Severe fatty degeneration of the paraspinal muscle was identified as an independent risk factor for domino OVFs.
population_specificity: Patients (n = 190) treated conservatively for acute OVFs in 8 hospitals with a 12-month follow-up.

study_goal: To determine the effect of Easy-Flex as an adjunct to standard inpatient rehabilitation on clinical and functional outcomes, particularly in improving range of motion, pain, and gait speed.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in flexion ROM, pain reduction, gait speed, and physical component summary scores in the Easy-Flex Group compared to the Control Group, with some outcomes exceeding the minimum clinically important difference.
population_specificity: 44 patients undergoing rehabilitation, likely post-total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: 30-40 minutes of exercise with Easy-Flex integrated into a 20-minute rehabilitation program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a counseling intervention designed to increase walking reduced the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The counseling intervention significantly reduced the risk of MACE compared to the control group (9.8% vs. 21.4%), with improvements in quality of life scores associated with lower MACE risk. However, after adjusting for quality of life scores, the intervention's association with reduced MACE risk was no longer significant.
population_specificity: Patients with walking impairment due to PAD from vascular departments in Australian cities (Brisbane, Sydney, Townsville).
effective_dosage: Four brief counseling sessions (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the characteristics, risk factors, and clinical significance of post-COVID interstitial lung disease (ILD) in patients with persistent respiratory symptoms after COVID-19 recovery.
results_summary: The study found that post-COVID ILD was prevalent in 262 out of 375 patients, with dyspnea, exercise intolerance, fatigue, and cough being common symptoms. Functional and radiological improvements occurred spontaneously in 13.4% and 20.6% of patients, respectively, by the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent respiratory symptoms 3 months after recovery from COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the real-world effectiveness of the On the Move (OTM) exercise program on improving mobility in older adults, assess intervention fidelity, and identify factors impacting fidelity.
results_summary: The study found that OTM, delivered by community instructors, improved gait speed in older adults, with benefits persisting post-intervention. It also assessed fidelity and identified organizational, instructor, and participant-level factors influencing program effectiveness.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (502 participants across 44 sites).

study_goal: To determine whether multicomponent exercise (MCE) is more effective than single exercise in improving walking ability in stroke patients.
results_summary: MCE significantly improved gait speed in stroke survivors. Prolonging MCE time may enhance walking endurance.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of audio-biofeedback versus traditional methods (bathroom scale) in teaching partial weight-bearing adherence in older adults and to assess the influence of individual characteristics on load adherence.
results_summary: No significant difference in weight-bearing adherence was found between the audio-biofeedback and scale groups. Overloading occurred in both groups during walking, step-up, and step-down activities, and was associated with lower cognitive function, older age, and higher BMI.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 60+ without gait impairment.
effective_dosage: Partial weight-bearing of 20 kg was trained.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combining repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) with body weight-support treadmill training (BWSTT) for improving walking function in individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
results_summary: The study found that combining BWSTT with real rTMS led to earlier gait improvement (after 6 sessions) compared to sham treatment, though differences between groups diminished by the 12th session. Lower extremity motor function and mobility scores improved in the real rTMS group but not the sham group, while sensory function, functional independence, and quality of life remained similar between groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI)
effective_dosage: 10 Hz rTMS (1800 pulses per session) combined with BWSTT (15-20 min, moderate intensity)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize complex walking situations, understand behavioral adaptations in ageing and neurological populations, and report clinical applications of complex walking.
results_summary: The study found that complex walking tasks, especially when combined with cognitive tasks, place greater strain on attentional resources, leading to declines in walking or cognitive performance. It highlights complex walking's potential for early detection of cognitive impairments and falls, as well as its value in cognitive-motor rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Ageing and neurological populations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise-based prehabilitation impacts postoperative outcomes in adults undergoing colorectal surgery.
results_summary: Prehabilitation reduced postoperative hospital stay and improved preoperative functional outcomes but did not significantly reduce complications or readmissions compared to standard care or rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a VR-HMD "walker avoidance" game in reducing step-aside reaction time and enhancing agility in collision avoidance during walking.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant decreases in step-aside reaction times (both standing and walking) and improved agility compared to the control group, with fewer collisions and quicker toe-off movements after training.
population_specificity: 30 young adults (15 in experimental group, 15 in control group).
effective_dosage: Two sessions of the "walker avoidance" game, conducted 1 week apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine factors associated with participation in the walking component of a cognitive behavioral intervention for Veterans with chronic pain who smoke.
results_summary: The study found that older age and lower extremity pain were associated with increased odds of being sedentary (≤ 4999 daily steps). Median daily steps were 2491 for sedentary participants and 7307 for non-sedentary participants.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic pain who smoke (91.0% men, 70.5% white, mean age 58.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of proprioceptive training strategies with dual-task exercises on gait parameters in people with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Dual-task proprioceptive training improved gait speed, cadence, stride time, stride length, and step length in chronic stroke patients, with optimal effects observed at 3 sessions per week for 4 weeks (30 minutes per session).
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (393 participants, 241 in the dual-task group).
effective_dosage: 3 times a week for 4 weeks, 30 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) therapy for managing Parkinson's disease (PD), focusing on neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and regenerative properties.
results_summary: The abstract highlights preclinical and clinical evidence supporting MSC therapy for PD but does not provide specific results related to walking or its effects. It discusses challenges such as delivery methods, timing, and long-term safety.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 12 weeks of rebound therapy on walking parameters in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: Rebound therapy training significantly improved all dependent variables related to walking parameters in SCI patients after 12 weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: Thirty members of Isfahan Spinal Cord Injury Association with spinal cord injuries.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week of rebound therapy exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish evidence-based guidelines for the return to running process following a tibial bone stress injury (BSI), focusing on criteria for clinical decision-making.
results_summary: The study found that successful return to running after a tibial BSI requires addressing five key components: resolution of bony tenderness, pain-free walking, radiological healing in high-risk BSIs, strength and functional tests, and identification of contributing factors. An individualized, graduated return-to-running program, often starting with walk-run intervals, was recommended.
population_specificity: Long-distance runners with tibial bone stress injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of vibration-HAFO versus standard HAFO on gait, function, and spasticity in children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Vibration-HAFO significantly improved one-minute walking test performance, spasticity, and several gait parameters (step width, hip abduction, dorsiflexion, pelvic tilt) compared to standard HAFO. Some kinematic improvements were noted, but no significant changes in knee parameters were observed.
population_specificity: Children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy (n=23, ages not specified).
effective_dosage: Mean vibration use was 16.83 minutes per day.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the impact of environmental and lifestyle factors, including birth month, on disease progression in Multiple Sclerosis (MS), particularly the need for walking assistance.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with MS born in January had a higher risk of requiring walking assistance compared to those born in other months, suggesting a potential link between gestational period and long-term disease progression.
population_specificity: Individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: To evaluate the feasibility of implementing a self-management intervention to improve mobility and walking in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible to implement, with high retention rates (83% at 3 months, 79.2% at 6 months). Participants perceived improvements in mobility, though adherence varied and efficacy could not be conclusively determined due to the study's small sample size.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors within six months post-discharge from hospital with functional and cognitive capacity for self-management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of walking in a suggested environment versus free walking on physical activity levels in individuals with COPD.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to assess physical activity levels, exercise capacity, quality of life, dyspnea, motivation, anxiety, depression, and environmental perceptions, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 38 volunteers diagnosed with COPD recruited from a pulmonary physiotherapy and rehabilitation service.
effective_dosage: Progressive walks carried out 3 to 5 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of efzimfotase alfa in adults with Hypophosphatasia (HPP), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that efzimfotase alfa had acceptable safety and pharmacokinetic profiles, with dose-dependent reductions in disease biomarkers (PPi and PLP), but it did not assess Walking.
population_specificity: Adults with Hypophosphatasia (HPP).
effective_dosage: 15 mg, 45 mg, or 90 mg (one intravenous dose followed by 3 weekly subcutaneous doses).
study_duration: Not specified beyond the dosing schedule.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a fully powered RCT to evaluate the effectiveness of prefabricated contoured foot orthoses, prescribed via telehealth, in increasing physical activity (walking) for people with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that prefabricated contoured foot orthoses positively affected physical activity (2590 steps/day increase) and showed comparable outcomes for hip-related quality of life and pain, with high adherence and low dropout rates.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (prefabricated contoured foot orthoses vs. flat shoe inserts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether supplementing wearable activity monitors with a game-based social media intervention (CHALLENGE) could increase step count and motivation for physical activity in insufficiently active older women.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial comparing the CHALLENGE intervention (wearable monitor plus social media challenges) to a monitor-only group, with assessments at 6, 12, and 18 months to measure step count and motivation. Results are pending, but the hypothesis is that playful experiences will improve motivation and sustain step count increases.
population_specificity: Healthy, community-dwelling older adult women who are insufficiently active.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical manifestations, imaging features, and etiology of Wernekinck commissure syndrome (WCS), particularly focusing on the occurrence of palatal myoclonus in the early stages.
results_summary: The study found that a patient with WCS secondary to midbrain infarction showed rapid improvement in walking and speech after 7 days of treatment with dual antiplatelet therapy, intensive statin therapy, and blood pressure/glucose adjustments. Palatal myoclonus, typically a late phenomenon, was observed early in this case.
population_specificity: A 68-year-old right-handed East Asian man with risk factors for ischemic cerebrovascular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise and multidisciplinary prehabilitation interventions on postoperative hospital length of stay and functional capacity in colorectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that prehabilitation interventions significantly reduced postoperative hospital length of stay by nearly 2 days and improved functional capacity, as measured by VO2 peak and 6-minute walking test. The effects were consistent across randomized and nonrandomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing resection of colorectal cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and radiological outcomes of two surgical techniques (SAPF and MI-TLIF) for improving walking ability and reducing pain in patients with degenerative disc disease and lumbar instability.
results_summary: Both surgical techniques significantly improved walking distance after 24 months, with no significant difference between the two methods. Pain and functional outcomes also improved, but neither technique was superior to the other.
population_specificity: Adult patients with single-level L4-L5 or L5-S1 lumbar stenosis and minor lumbar instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of boots on walking biomechanics compared to casual footwear, focusing on joint kinematics, kinetics, and potential injury risks.
results_summary: Walking with boots increased hip and knee joint loading and altered biomechanics, potentially raising the risk of musculoskeletal injuries and osteoarthritis, while restricting ankle movement. The study suggests compensatory adjustments in the hip and knee due to ankle restrictions.
population_specificity: 20 healthy male participants aged 20 to 30 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of two surgical approaches (DAA and PA) for total hip arthroplasty (THA), focusing on factors like pain, complications, and recovery.
results_summary: The DAA group showed lower pain scores at 1 and 2 days post-THA, higher prosthesis placement accuracy, and shorter hospital stays but had higher risks of intraoperative fractures and nerve injuries. No significant differences were found in walking aid cessation time, dislocation rates, or other complications.
population_specificity: 14,478 participants undergoing THA (4,911 in DAA group, 9,567 in PA group).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up times varied by outcome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a functional intervention within a cognitive approach for patients with chronic cervical radiculopathy, promoting general physical activities like walking as part of non-surgical treatment.
results_summary: The study proposed a 12-week functional intervention that included walking and simple exercises, focusing on self-management and staying active, but did not report specific outcomes for walking alone.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic cervical radiculopathy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of perturbation-based balance training (PBT) versus regular treadmill walking on physical, cognitive, and sociopsychological factors in older adults at multiple time points.
results_summary: PBT showed short-term improvements in choice stepping reaction time and dual-task gait speed compared to treadmill walking, but these benefits were not sustained at 6- or 12-month follow-ups. No significant differences were found in other physical, cognitive, or sociopsychological measures.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged ≥65.
study_duration: Short-term (post-training), with follow-ups at 6 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, components, and dosage of interventions, including walking, for improving upright balance control, balance confidence, and reducing falls in adults with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury/disease (SCI/D).
results_summary: Walking interventions and upright balance training with visual feedback showed clinically meaningful and significant effects on improving standing balance control. Only walking interventions significantly improved balance confidence, but no significant dosage response was found.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-74 with chronic, motor-incomplete SCI/D (males: females = 2.4:1).

study_goal: To systematically review the evidence for intensive mobility training in cerebral palsy (CP) and determine the minimum effective dose to improve mobility.
results_summary: Task-oriented training (TOT) significantly improved walking speed, cadence, gross motor function, and functional mobility compared to control interventions, though the threshold dose was undeterminable due to high heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Participants with cerebral palsy (mean age range 1 year 2 months to 16 years 4 months).
effective_dosage: Not specified (high heterogeneity prevented determination of threshold dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intermittent theta-burst stimulation (iTBS) on gait, balance, and lower limb motor function in stroke recovery, while exploring underlying neural mechanisms.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial assessing iTBS's impact on walking ability and related outcomes in stroke survivors, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 46 stroke survivors with impaired walking ability.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of iTBS (600 pulses per session) over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical performance of an intramedullary nail combined with a reconstruction plate versus a single intramedullary nail for treating unstable intertrochanteric femoral fractures with a fractured lateral femoral wall during walking.
results_summary: The study found that combining an intramedullary nail with a reconstruction plate (ITN/RP) increased construct stiffness by 29%, reduced peak stress on implants by 24%, lowered femur stress by 23%, and decreased displacement by 12% compared to using a single intramedullary nail (ITN).
population_specificity: A three-dimensional finite element femur model derived from computed tomography images of a healthy male volunteer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) followed by treadmill training (TT) on dual-task walking performance and cortical excitability in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that 12 sessions of DLPFC tDCS followed by TT significantly improved cognitive dual-task walking (CDTW) performance and reduced cortical excitability more than TT alone in PD patients. The combined intervention showed greater benefits in gait rehabilitation compared to sham tDCS with TT.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (34 participants).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of tDCS followed by 30 minutes of TT per session, 12 sessions within 5 weeks (2-3 sessions per week).

study_goal: To determine if the Assistive Device Selection, Training, and Education Program (ADSTEP) reduces falls and improves outcomes in people with MS who use walking aids.
results_summary: The ADSTEP group showed a significant decrease in fall rates, increased physical activity, and improved walking aid fit compared to the control group.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS) who use walking aids and have a history of falls.
effective_dosage: Six weekly one-on-one virtual sessions with a physical therapist.
study_duration: 6 weeks (intervention) with follow-up assessments at 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of rectus femoris diagnostic motor nerve blocks (DNB) with anaesthetics and botulinum toxin (BoNT-A) injections on walking performance in multiple sclerosis patients with unilateral stiff-knee gait.
results_summary: Positive results from DNB correlated with significant functional improvements after BoNT-A, particularly in endurance and walking speed. Higher disability scores and longer time since diagnosis were associated with poorer outcomes.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis patients in stable condition with unilateral stiff-knee gait.
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted before and 1 hour after DNB, and 1 month after BoNT-A injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether locomotor training in a movement amplification environment improves walking balance and participation in walking activities more effectively than traditional treadmill training for people with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that movement amplification during treadmill walking will enhance walking balance and participation in walking activities for individuals with iSCI, but results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Ambulatory participants with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI)
study_duration: Not specified (number of sessions provided, but not duration in weeks/months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the use of cervical vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (cVEMPs) for assessing vestibular function in infants, particularly those with hearing loss, to support early intervention for gross motor and cognitive development.
results_summary: The review found a lack of consensus on stimulus and recording parameters for infant cVEMPs and noted decreased cVEMP response rates with severe to profound hearing loss. It highlighted the need for standardized protocols and large-scale studies to improve vestibular screening in infants with hearing loss.
population_specificity: Infants, particularly those diagnosed with sensorineural hearing loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term efficacy of an exercise program using the wearable cyborg Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) lumbar type in improving physical function, particularly walking speed, in mobility-limited older adults.
results_summary: The 5-week HAL lumbar type exercise program significantly improved usual and maximum walking speeds, Timed Up and Go test results, chair-standing test results, and GLFS-5 scores in the intervention group compared to controls, with no changes in body composition.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age ~75 years) with physical frailty or locomotive syndrome who do not require nursing care.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 5 weeks (trunk and gait training sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the probability of walking independence in hospitalized patients with vertebral compression fractures (VCFs) and develop a clinical prediction rule (CPR) for this outcome.
results_summary: The study found that 78.3% of VCF patients achieved walking independence, with cognitive function and Berg Balance Scale (BBS) scores (cut-off of 45 points) as significant predictors. The developed CPR had high diagnostic accuracy (AUC 0.92) and performed well in internal validation.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥60 years hospitalized for VCF at four hospitals in Japan (2019-2022).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop data-driven prediction models for segmental motor recovery after spinal cord injury to improve rehabilitation programs and clinical trial sensitivity.
results_summary: The study achieved accurate predictions of motor score recovery (RMSE 0.76) and functional outcomes (AUC not specified), validated across European and American datasets. The kNN model performed comparably to regression models in predicting independent walking and self-care ability.
population_specificity: Patients with traumatic spinal cord injury (1267 from European Multicenter Study, 411 from Sygen trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether custom-made insoles adapted to flip-flops improved pain intensity, foot function, and functional walking ability in individuals with persistent plantar heel pain.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between custom-made insoles and sham insoles in reducing pain intensity, improving foot function, or enhancing functional walking ability at 6 weeks, 12 weeks, or 4 weeks post-intervention. All observed differences were smaller than the minimum clinically important difference.
population_specificity: Individuals with persistent plantar heel pain.
